@graph.title: Efficient finite-volume schemes for magnetohydrodynamic simulations in solar physics
@graph.abstract: Abstract: We present efficient finite-volume schemes for solving<br>the equations of (compressible) magnetohydrodynamics (MHD) in one, two, and<br>three spatial dimensions. We introduce a new approximate Riemann solver for the<br>ideal gas MHD equations (MHD-HLLEM) that outperforms all other solvers<br>considered. We present and compare several Riemann solvers that are suitable<br>for the real gas case of an arbitrary equation of state (EOS) (e.g., RGDW and<br>RGMHD-HLLEM). If the evaluation of the EOS is expensive, we suggest using an<br>adaptively-refined table for the EOS. Our error indicator facilitates a<br>significant enhancement of the codes' efficiencies by using locally-adapted<br>grids. We introduce a new limiter (DEOmod) for linear reconstructions on<br>unstructured triangular grids in 2d that represents a clear improvement of<br>the approaches commonly used. Simulations in physically-unbounded domains are<br>enabled by the proposed transparent boundary conditions. We show that the new<br>hyperbolic divergence cleaning technique is a highly effective and efficient<br>approach for reducing errors in the divergence of the numerical approximation<br>to the magnetic field. Our 3d code is parallelized for distributed-memory<br>machines and comprises dynamic load balancing and local grid adaption on<br>unstructured hexahedral or tetrahedral grids.<br><br>All our comparisons of solvers are based on considering their efficiencies,<br>i.e., the computational time required for reaching the same errors.<br>We construct one- and two-dimensional<br>Riemann problems whose exact solution is known at least in parts of the<br>computational domain. The suitability and efficiency of our multidimensional<br>codes for applications from solar physics is demonstrated by simulations of<br>magnetic fluxtubes. However, neither our new approaches nor their<br>implementations are restricted to solar physics. Furthermore, our new limiter<br>and the error indicator can be used for arbitrary time-dependent hyperbolic<br>systems of conservation laws
